utterances: This hour, we'll talk with conservatives and liberals about what happened to both political parties on Tuesday and how their ideologies may change.
Later in the hour, we'll talk with FCC Commissioner Jonathan Adelstein about the FCC's new rulings on profanity.
But first we want to hear from you.
Did the Democrats win or the Republicans lose?
Should Democrats work with the president when they can or oppose him at every turn?
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
E-mail talk@NPR.org.
Joining us now is Adrian Woodridge - the Washington Bureau chief of The Economist magazine, co-author of the Right Nation: Conservative Power in America.
He joins us here in studio 3A.
Nice to have you back on the program.
Thank you.
Is this truly a significant shift, do you think?
Well, I'm trying to write a new book called The Left Nation.
Not quite.
I don't think this a significant shift.
What it is a corrective and a reassertion of the power of the center.

People aren't saying we want to move dramatically to the left, but what they're saying is that the Republican Party and the conservative movement just tried to take us too far to the right and we didn't want any more marching in that direction.
Mm-hmm.
So what message should we take?
I mean you see all kinds of commentators from the right saying, well, we lost our way in the wilderness of the Washington bureaucracy.
We became, well, like Democrats.
We got fat and happy and forgot our good, conservative values.
I think there's some truth in that.
The - what we see here is partly a rejection of incumbency.
These are people who lost their ideas and became just concerned with being insiders, with doling out pork, with doling out committee chairmanships.
So it's partly that but there is something more here, and that is that there is a rejection of a particular set of ideas, and that is the neoconservative ideas that led to the Iraq war.
I think for an incumbent senator who's part of a party leadership to lose by more than 14 points is very dramatic.
It's not been given the attention it should have been.

So I think what we've seen is that big government conservativism alienates real conservatives, small government conservatives without winning over the sort of swing voters that it's intended to win over.
Bush has been, in some ways, a very ideological president, not just a White House insider, but somebody who took the country in a really new direction.
I think the whole idea of destroying rogue states, asserting American power, using American military force to change the balance of power in this or that area of the world - these were ideas.
These weren't things that were pushed for by the permanent bureaucracy.
These are things that were pushed forward by a very identifiable group of conservative intellectuals.
And what we have seen is those ideas leading into a morass in Iraq and voters going to the polls and saying, look, this is a mess.
We don't want any more of it.
Though it is an ideological defeat as well as the defeat for incumbents.

For many years, conservatives argued that their side enjoyed the ideological fervor, that the ideas that were - even during the Clinton administration, welfare reform, for example - that these were generated from the right.
Yesterday and after Tuesday of this week, they seem to be on the defensive.
The right's on the defensive, but I think certainly, the neoconservative movement is on the defensive.
I'm not sure that what we see is a terrible foment of ideas on the left, however.

What we see is a very careful - a very good set of policy proposals by Nancy Pelosi - very sensible, centrist set of ideas - but not a real identity, not a real ideological identity in the way that you got with Newt Gingrich.
I applaud that.
My worry is that you will get a set - a new ideological movement, which will be an attempt to redefine centrism in a very different way from the way that Clinton defined it.
And that will be, shall I call it, leudovisism(ph).
It will be protectionism, building up walls against immigrants, building up walls against trade, and taking a culturally conservative position.
Sort of a left-wing Buchananism as it were.
I see some signs of that.
Coming out of the Democratic Party?
Yes, coming out of the Democratic Party because they're trying to become a - less of a liberal party, more of a national party.
They're trying to become less of a fringe party, more of a centrist party.
The real question that we're going to see debated over the next few months, I think, is what is this new centrism?

Well, at the same time - I was talking about the conservatives saying that we lost our way and we have to get back to true conser… You also see progressives arguing that no, it wasn't that the conservatives - Democrats who won this election, it was progressives who won this election.
They were the fervor behind getting people to the polls and getting people excited about this election.
Sure.
Do you see people arguing that?
I think the case of Ned Lamont's doesn't necessarily demonstrate - I think the really interesting thing that's happened from the Democratic point of view…
Ned Lamont, the anti-war insurgent who upset Joe Lieberman in Connecticut but then lost to him as an Independent in the general election on Tuesday.
Exactly right.
I think what you're seeing is the fact that they're making inroads into places like Iowa and Idaho and Kansas.
The fact that they are more of a centrist party, they're willing to - or more of a big-tent party, shall I say.
They're not a culturally elitist party.
They're trying not to be.
And I think that Nancy Pelosi is trying to produce an agenda, which is as broad - I don't want to call it banal - but it's not exactly full of cutting-edge ideas.
This is as broad as you can be in order to try and hold this big-tent party together.
Let's get some callers involved in the conversation.
If you'd like to join us, our number is 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK and the e-mail address is talk@NPR.org.
We'll begin with Neil, Neil calling us from San Antonio, Texas.
Yes.
How are you all?
Very well.
Thanks.
Very good.

I was just calling to tell you that I consider myself conservative but I voted straight Libertarian this time, just because I've really gotten kind of turned off by the fact that Bush hadn't stayed the course on a lot of conservative ideas.
I've gotten - I was very disappointed in his position on the steel tariffs; the soft wood lumber tariffs; medical benefits that haven't been paid for; the cost of war; the ballooning budget deficit.
And it seems to me that every time there's a chance to spend money, they do.

And I'm hoping - everybody's saying that it's a referendum on the war and I'm looking at it as more of a referendum on stop the spending, and let's get under - our financial house under control or we're all going to be in trouble.
Yes -
I was just wondering what y'all thought.
Adrian Woodridge, the Republican Party used to be the party of a small government and low taxes - still got the small taxes - but small government, no, that's not true.
Exactly, I think what George Bush tried to do in order to broaden the conservative and the Republican coalition, was to create something which has been termed big government conservativism.
This was trying to use the power of government to push for conservative ends.
And this election was very much a repudiation of that.
We have Rick Santorum, who is a man who believed in big government and using that government for socially conservative ends going down to a really spectacular defeat in Pennsylvania.
So I think that we're seeing the terminus of that particular movement, for a while, at least.
And, Neil, you weren't convinced by the talk of fiscal austerity on the part of the Democrats?
They have proved it before.

And I think everybody was saying what a great job Clinton did, but I really believe that the, you know, income grew in to his budget, not that the budget decreased or there was any decrease in spending.
Well, there were losses - real losses in the number of people who worked for the government during the Clinton administration and that did reverse during the Bush administration, Neil.
But anyway…
That's true but if you look I bet you the overall expenditures actually went up.
Yeah, I think that's true of the Reagan administration, too, but let's not fight old battles.
But what could Reagan do when you had a Democratic Congress?
I wish Reagan had a Republican Congress is really what I wish could have happened.
All right, Neil.
Thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's get Francine(ph) on.
Francine from Denver, Colorado.
Hi.
This is a red state that went purple this time, and swung the congressional districts from four to three Republicans to three to four Democrat.
I think the end of an era is definitely in place but it wasn't just the war in Iraq, and I think the Democrats are going to be wrong if they get co-opted by Bush.
His habit is to make statements in public and then act completely different in private.
If they stick just to Iraq, which is a total quagmire no matter who's in office, we're going to lose the 2008 presidential election.
I think people voted also because they're tired of the religious right ruining the country, and in Colorado we have Focus in the Family and the Republican Party is way, way right.
Get back to science as the principal of objectively analyzing problems.
And everyone is called a liberal out here.
Every Democrat who runs, no matter what they think, is tagged liberal so you might as well live up to the name a bit.
And I think any Democrat who ran this time, contrary to the beliefs of the Democratic Party in my state, would have one.
And many people almost won.
So I think, if I were a Republican strategist, I'd definitely draw the Democrats in on Iraq and thereby losing that momentum to change.

And if I were a Democrat I would really concentrate on the old-fashioned, you know, Democratic wing of the Democratic Party and redefine the center, because the center has got - you know, we talk about this was the center, but actually, 20 Republican - 20 Democrat - pro-choice Democrats replaced anti-choice Republicans and that's actually something that no Democrat is talking about.
I don't mean to cut you off, Francine, but I wanted to give Adrian Wooldridge a chance to reply before the break.
Sure.
Well, I think it's very interesting what has happened in Colorado and in the West, that we have a Democratic trend.
And we could be seeing the beginning of a lot of Western states going the way that California has gone because the West tends to be socially liberal.
If it's economically conservative, it's also socially liberal.
And so I think that's an extremely worrying sign from the Republican point of view.
They could become the party of the South, that finds it very difficult - impossible, of course, to win over the Northeast - but also very difficult to win over the West.
So Colorado is certainly a state that needs to be carefully watched.
Francine, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
Bye.
Bye-bye.
And Adrian Wooldridge, we appreciate your coming in today.
Thank you very much.
Adrian Wooldridge, the Washington bureau chief of The Economist magazine, coauthor of The Right Nation: Conservative Power in America.
When we come back from a break we'll take more of your calls on this issue as we continue the conversation.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
